rules.title: Detect Office Applications Spawning Command Shells Indicative of Phishing
rules.description: Detects WINWORD.EXE or EXCEL.EXE processes creating cmd.exe or powershell.exe processes, with PowerShell command lines containing encoded payload indicators. This behavior is typical of malicious macros delivered via phishing emails.

detection.condition: selection1 or selection2 or selection3 or selection4

falsepositives: Legitimate Office macros that invoke command-line tools for automation or reporting
IT administrative scripts that use Excel/Word to launch PowerShell for configuration tasks
User‑initiated data processing workflows that involve Office applications calling scripts

rules.title: Suspicious Process Connecting to Known Tunneling Ports (TCP 636, 994, 995)
rules.description: Detects processes that initiate network connections to TCP ports commonly abused for protocol tunneling (636, 994, 995). Includes exclusions for legitimate services such as LDAPS (lsass.exe) and POP3S (outlook.exe).

detection.condition: ((suspicious_process and tunnel_ports) or (enc_cmd and tunnel_ports)) and not (legit_ldaps or legit_pop3s)

falsepositives: Legitimate LDAPS traffic from lsass.exe or other directory services.
Outbound POP3S connections from Outlook or other email clients.
Administrative scripts using PowerShell or Python to connect to internal services on these ports.

attacks.command: netsh advfirewall firewall add rule name="AllowOutbound123" dir=out action=allow protocol=TCP localport=123
attacks.description: Basic: Create a Windows Firewall rule to allow outbound traffic on a specific port, potentially for C&C communication.
attacks.expected_behavior: A new outbound rule is created in the Windows Firewall, allowing traffic on the specified port.

attacks.command: netsh advfirewall firewall delete rule name="AllowOutbound123" && netsh advfirewall firewall add rule name="AllowOutbound123" dir=out action=allow protocol=TCP localport=123
attacks.description: Intermediate: Delete and then recreate a Windows Firewall rule to allow outbound traffic, simulating a potential defense evasion technique.
attacks.expected_behavior: The specified outbound rule is first deleted and then recreated, potentially evading detection by briefly altering the system's defense configuration.

attacks.description: Advanced: Utilize PowerShell to create a new outbound Windows Firewall rule, allowing traffic on a specific port, demonstrating a more sophisticated approach to impairing system defenses.
attacks.expected_behavior: A new outbound Windows Firewall rule is created using PowerShell, enabling traffic on the specified port, and potentially facilitating undetected communication with C&C servers.

attacks.description: Add a rule to allow output traffic to port 80
attacks.expected_behavior: The rule will be added to the OUTPUT chain, allowing traffic to port 80

attacks.description: Delete a rule to allow output traffic to port 80
attacks.expected_behavior: The rule will be deleted from the OUTPUT chain, blocking traffic to port 80

attacks.description: Flush all rules and add a new rule to allow output traffic to port 443
attacks.expected_behavior: All existing rules will be deleted, and a new rule will be added to the OUTPUT chain, allowing traffic to port 443

attacks.command: echo "Sensitive data for testing" > /tmp/clear.txt && openssl enc -aes-256-cbc -salt -pbkdf2 -pass pass:MySecretPass -in /tmp/clear.txt -out /tmp/obf.enc
attacks.description: Intermediate obfuscation: encrypts the file using OpenSSL AES‑256‑CBC with a password, producing binary ciphertext.
attacks.expected_behavior: Writes the plaintext to /tmp/clear.txt, then creates /tmp/obf.enc containing the encrypted data.

attacks.description: Advanced obfuscation: compresses selected system files, encrypts the archive with OpenSSL, and base64‑encodes the result for safe transport.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a base64‑encoded, encrypted tarball of /etc/hostname and /etc/hosts and stores it in /tmp/obf_payload.b64.

attacks.expected_behavior: A file named hook.ps1 is created in the temporary directory with the contents 'Hello World'

attacks.description: Basic command to write a test string to a file in /tmp
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file named test_file.txt in /tmp with the string 'test_string'

attacks.description: Intermediate command to create a cron job that appends a test string to a file every minute
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a cron job that appends 'test_string' to /tmp/test_file.txt every minute

attacks.description: Advanced command to modify the /etc/motd file with a test string (requires admin privileges)
attacks.expected_behavior: Appends 'test_string' to the /etc/motd file, requiring admin privileges

attacks.description: Basic command to execute a simple script using cmd.exe
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file named test.txt in the temporary directory with the content 'Hello World'

attacks.description: Intermediate command to execute an encoded command using PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file named test.txt in the temporary directory with the content 'Hello world'

attacks.description: Advanced command to execute a multi-step command using cmd.exe and a batch script
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a batch script named test.bat in the temporary directory, which when executed, prints 'Hello World' to the console

attacks.description: Basic example of executing a bash command
attacks.expected_behavior: Prints 'Hello World' to the console

attacks.description: Intermediate example of executing a bash command to list directory contents
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists the current directory's contents in a detailed format

attacks.description: Advanced example of executing a bash command to list all running processes
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists all running processes on the system

attacks.description: Basic remote file creation using SSH to simulate lateral movement
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a directory and a file on the remote host to demonstrate remote service usage

attacks.description: Intermediate file transfer using SCP to simulate data movement between hosts
attacks.expected_behavior: Transfers a local file to a remote host, demonstrating lateral movement of data

attacks.description: Advanced directory synchronization using Rsync to simulate more complex data movement
attacks.expected_behavior: Synchronizes a local directory with a remote directory, demonstrating more complex lateral movement capabilities

attacks.description: Gather general system information
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays general system information, including OS version, hardware, and network settings.

attacks.description: Collect disk information, potentially indicating SSD storage
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists disk status, size, and free space, which can help identify SSDs based on their typical sizes and performance characteristics.

attacks.description: Query system for disk information, focusing on SSD indicators
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays disk size in GB and indicates whether each disk is an SSD based on its bus type.

attacks.description: This command uses lsblk to list block devices, providing information about their type, size, mount point, and label, which can be useful for discovering system storage information.
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists block devices with their details.

attacks.description: This command reads the /proc/partitions file, which contains information about the disk partitions, including their major and minor numbers, the number of blocks, and the device name.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays information about disk partitions.

attacks.description: This command uses lshw to list detailed information about the disk class hardware, providing insights into the system's storage configuration.
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists detailed hardware information about disks, requiring admin privileges.

attacks.command: cmd.exe /c echo Hello > %TEMP%\test.txt && start cmd.exe /c type %TEMP%\test.txt
attacks.description: Create a new process using cmd.exe to execute a command
attacks.expected_behavior: A new command prompt window will open, displaying the contents of the test.txt file

attacks.description: Create a new process using powershell.exe to execute a command
attacks.expected_behavior: A new command prompt window will open, displaying the text 'Hello World!'

attacks.command: wmic.exe process call create "cmd.exe /c echo Hello > %TEMP%\test.txt"
attacks.description: Create a new process using wmic.exe to execute a command
attacks.expected_behavior: A new file test.txt will be created in the temp directory, containing the text 'Hello'

attacks.description: Create a new process using 'bash' to write a test string to a file
attacks.expected_behavior: A new file '/tmp/test.txt' will be created with the content 'Test String'

attacks.description: Create a new process using 'python' to execute a system command
attacks.expected_behavior: A new file '/tmp/test.py' will be created

attacks.description: Create a new process using 'bash' with elevated privileges to write a test string to a file
attacks.expected_behavior: A new file '/root/test.txt' will be created with the content 'Test String'

attacks.description: Creates a new boot entry, which could be used to simulate a pre-OS boot modification scenario.
attacks.expected_behavior: A new boot entry is created, which can be used for further testing or simulation.

attacks.description: Simulates removing a boot configuration file, demonstrating potential pre-OS boot manipulation.
attacks.expected_behavior: If the specified boot configuration file exists, it is removed. This simulates a scenario where a malicious actor might alter boot configurations.

attacks.description: Adds a registry value to simulate a pre-OS boot environment modification.
attacks.expected_behavior: A new registry value named 'BootTest' with the data 'TestBoot' is added under the specified key, simulating a modification to the system's environment.

attacks.description: Create a test file in the /etc directory to simulate potential persistence
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named testfile.txt will be created in the /etc directory containing the string 'Test String'

attacks.description: Create a test directory in the /boot directory to simulate potential persistence
attacks.expected_behavior: A directory named testdir will be created in the /boot directory

attacks.description: Copy a harmless system binary to a location that could be used for persistence, simulating malware placement
attacks.expected_behavior: The /bin/true binary will be copied to /etc/init.d/testscript, potentially simulating malicious script placement

attacks.description: Lists all running services on the local machine, which can be used to discover network services.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays a list of running services.

attacks.description: Displays detailed information about the TCP/IP configuration of all network adapters, which can be used to discover network services and configurations.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays detailed TCP/IP configuration information.

attacks.description: Uses PowerShell to get all TCP connections that are in the listening state, which can indicate network services waiting for incoming connections.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays a list of TCP connections in the listening state.

attacks.description: Basic network service discovery using TCP SYN scanning
attacks.expected_behavior: Output will show open TCP ports and corresponding services

attacks.description: Intermediate network service discovery using netstat to list all listening ports
attacks.expected_behavior: Output will show all listening ports and corresponding services

attacks.description: Advanced network service discovery using ss to list all listening ports and sockets
attacks.expected_behavior: Output will show all listening ports, sockets, and corresponding services

attacks.description: Basic example of archiving a file using Compress-Archive
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates an archive.zip file in the TEMP directory containing test.txt

attacks.command: powershell -Command "mkdir $env:TEMP\collected_data -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue; Get-Process | Out-File $env:TEMP\collected_data\process_list.txt; Compress-Archive -Path $env:TEMP\collected_data -DestinationPath $env:TEMP\collected_data_archive.zip -Force; Remove-Item $env:TEMP\collected_data -Recurse -Force"
attacks.description: Advanced example of collecting process list, archiving, and then cleaning up
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a directory, collects process list, archives it, and then removes the directory

attacks.description: This command collects data from a specified path and archives it using 'tar' with gzip compression.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will create a compressed archive named 'collected_data.tar.gz' containing the data from the specified path.

attacks.description: This command uses 'zip' to archive data from a specified path, creating a zip file named 'collected_data.zip'.
attacks.expected_behavior: A zip archive named 'collected_data.zip' will be created, containing the data from the specified path.

attacks.description: This command utilizes '7z' to create an archive named 'collected_data.7z' containing the data from the specified path.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will generate a '7z' archive named 'collected_data.7z', containing the specified data.
